III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited
to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A was placed in a headlock during a restraint attempt.
Investigation The Complainant was contacted on 07/24/2024 and had no
additional information to provide.
Youth A was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 over the phone on
07/22/2024. Youth A stated he had hit his own head on a window
during an escalation. He believed the window broke when he did
this. Afterwards Youth A recalled hearing Staff 4 direct him to go
sit down away from the broken glass. Youth A stated Staff 4 then
grabbed him by the neck and threw him to the ground. Youth A
stated he then bit Staff 4 to get Staff 4 off of him. Youth A also
remembered accidentally kicking another staff member during the
incident but could not identify who that was. Youth A could not
recall any other youth or staff that were present. He stated this all
occurred in the hallway of one of the units. Youth A recalled
eventually calming down and then going to the hospital to ensure
he didn’t injure himself.
An attempt to interview Youth B with DHHS Worker 1 during an
announced, face-to-face visit to the facility occurred on
08/02/2024 as a possible witness to the incident, but Youth B
refused the interview.
Staff 1 was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 08/02/2024
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She recalled
witnessing the incident in question first by hearing a commotion in
2

the lobby of the unit. She heard Youth A escalated and arguing
with Staff 4. Staff 1 encouraged him to go to another recreation
room, only for Youth A to throw his eyeglasses at her. Staff 1
moved out of the way and did not witness what occurred next, but
when she turned back around, she had seen Youth A on the floor
with Staff 4 attempting to perform a restraint. At that point Staff 1
continued to try to verbally de-escalate Youth A, and Youth A was
not responsive. He was kicking, spitting and threatening. Staff 4
recalled Youth A attempting to bite her and other staff members
that had come to assist. Staff 1 recalled Youth A having on a
hooded sweatshirt and in the commotion, it had ridden up on his
back and neck, and she attempted to move this back down so that
it did not choke him. Staff 1 never witnessed any other staff
members have Youth A in any position that resembled a headlock,
nor did she hear Youth A state that he felt like he could not
breathe.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on
08/02/2024 during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility.
Supervisor stated he reported to the incident after the restraint
had already begun and did not witness the preceding events. At
the time he arrived, Youth A was on the ground on his back
fighting against a restraint effort by other staff. Supervisor 1
stated Youth A was spitting and yelling, but he could not recall
specifically what Youth A was saying. He did recall Youth A was
very upset specifically at Staff 4, but Staff 4 was no longer
physically engaged with Youth A. Supervisor 1 stated he never
saw any staff member with their arms or bodies across Youth A,
and never heard anything from Youth A about struggling to breath.
Staff 2 was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 08/02/2024
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She
recalled Youth A being upset at the time she started her shift. She
witnessed him punch a door and state he was going to go to his
room, only then to stop in the hallway and throw his head
backwards into the glass window of the control room of the unit.
Staff 2 recalled Youth A then throwing his glasses and getting in
the face of Staff 4, who was nearby. Staff 4 initiated a restraint,
which quickly went to the ground with Youth A on his back and
fighting back at any staff nearby. Despite the fighting back Staff 2
recalled that at no point was anyone laying on top of Youth A or
doing anything that would have resembled a headlock. She did
recall Youth A yelling many things, including “You’re hurting me,”
but Staff 2 did not know what that could have been caused by. As
the restraint continued, Youth A eventually de-escalated and Staff
2 stayed with him. She recalled him expressing apologies for
3

charging at Staff 4, and at no point did he say anything about
being choked or having trouble breathing during the restraint.
Youth A did refer to his head hurting from hitting it on the window.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on
08/02/2024 during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility.
He stated that he became involved with Youth A during the
incident in the middle of the restraint effort. Supervisor 2 recalled
Youth A being in a supine position and he believed that staff were
properly attempting to hold Youth A’s arms and legs as he fought
back against them. Supervisor 2 recalled Youth A turning his
head and attempting to bite Staff 4 multiple times. Upon seeing
this, Supervisor 2 moved to take the place of Staff 4 so that Staff 4
could remove himself from the situation. After a short amount of
time Youth A began to de-escalate and the restraint was released.
Supervisor 2 stated that there were no points in time where Youth
A was in a headlock and he did not see any staff have contact
with Youth A’s head, neck or chest. Supervisor 2 also commented
that Youth A was yelling and screaming as he was escalated, but
he never heard a comment about not being able to breathe.
Staff 3 was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 08/02/2024
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She stated
that she saw Youth A punch a wall and then proceed to slam his
own head backwards into a window. At that point Youth A turned
his attention to Staff 4 and was acting aggressively toward him,
yelling threats and quickly moving into Staff 4’s personal space.
As this was occurring Staff 3 recalled Staff 4 instructing Youth A to
“take a seat, you probably got hurt” referring to him slamming his
head. Youth A yelled in response “Make me, bitch!”, “I’m gonna
beat your ass” and “I’m going to punch you” to Staff 4. Staff 3
recalled seeing Staff 4 put his hand out to keep Youth A at arm’s
length, and Youth A walked into Staff 4’s hand. Staff 4 then
initiated a standing restraint on Youth A, which quickly fell to the
ground when Youth A fought back at Staff 4. Staff 3 stated she
helped hold Youth A’s legs during the floor restraint while he was
on his back, but this was difficult as he was kicking. She recalled
seeing Staff 2 get kicked in the shoulder. Youth A did yell that he
could not breathe during the restraint, and Staff 3 noted he did not
stop yelling for much of the restraint effort until he started to calm
down. Staff 3 recalled the restraint lasting a few more minutes
until Youth A was able to calm down. Staff 3 never saw anyone
have Youth A in a chokehold or anyone laying over his chest or
neck area that would have restricted breathing.
4

Staff 4 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
08/09/2024. He recalled the incident in question beginning
because Youth A got upset about not being able to play a video
game. As Staff 4 attempted to reason with Youth A, he got more
upset and punched a wall and eventually hit his own head on a
window of the control room within the unit. Staff 4 recalled Youth
A then yelling threats that he wanted to kill staff and cut himself.
Staff 4 stated that he intentionally placed himself between Youth A
and the broken window so that he could not get to any glass
shards. Staff 4 recalled putting his hand out to protect his
personal space as Youth A advanced on him, telling Youth A to
take a seat. Youth A responded back “You don’t tell me to sit like
a dog.” Staff 4 stated to Youth A that if he continued to approach
him aggressively it would have to be taken as a physical threat.
Staff 4 stated Youth A then quickly approached him, and he
decided to initiate a standing restraint. Staff 4 recalled not being
able to do this successfully and because of Youth A’s aggression
they fell to the ground. He could not recall who, but another staff
quickly helped Staff 4 ensure that Youth A was in a supine
position and they each held one of his arms in a restraint position.
Staff 4 recalled Youth A continuing to be physically aggressive,
and he believed Youth A bit him on the hand at one point. Staff 4
recalled other staff taking over verbal de-escalation attempts and
he was eventually swapped out so that he could leave the
situation. Staff 4 thought this was best because Youth A was
continuing to direct verbal aggression specifically at him. During
the restraint Staff 4 was sure he never had Youth A in a
chokehold, nor did he or any other staff have any sort of pressure
on Youth A’s neck or chest that would have restricted his
breathing.
During a video conference on 08/14/2024 DHHS Worker 1
provided an update on her investigation and was not able to state
a final result at that time.
Video reviewed:
• Two angles of concurrent security camera footage of the
07/12/2024 incident were available. Both views allowed the
lobby area of the unit to be seen. View #1 faced the control
room and door that led to the bedrooms and connecting
hallway. View #2 faced the control room and outside exit of
the unit. In view #1 Youth A could be seen walking toward
the door to the bedroom hallway at 3:06:11 pm. He opened
the door and slammed it against the wall. Youth B then
walked past him and through the door towards the
bedrooms. Youth A was then seen yelling and visibly
5

upset, with Staff 2 and Staff 4 approximately ten feet away
from him. At 3:06:31 pm Youth A began to throw his head
backwards against the glass window of the unit, hitting it
three times. Staff 4 verbally addressed Youth A. Youth A
continued to be visibly upset as he approached Staff 4, and
at 3:07:07 Staff 4 attempted to perform a standing restraint
of Youth A. While attempting to hold Youth A’s arms from
behind him, Youth A struggled back and within 20 seconds
Youth A was on the floor with Staff 1 and Staff 2 attempting
to assist. View #1 did not show Staff 4 having Youth A in
any sort of headlock up to this point. In view #2 it could be
seen that Youth A’s hooded sweatshirt was riding up on his
upper body and back. View #2 showed Youth A being
taken to the ground by Staff 4 at 3:07:22 pm, resulting in
Staff 4 on his knees above Youth A’s chest for
approximately one minute. More staff came to assist as
Staff 2 and Staff 3 could be seen holding Youth A’s legs.
Supervisor 1 came in and replaced Staff 2 and Staff 3
holding Youth A’s legs. As Youth A continued to struggle
Supervisor 2 then helped Staff 4 disengage from Youth A.
The floor restraint lasted until 3:21:13 pm where Youth A
could be seen sitting up and receiving attention from
present staff.
Documentation reviewed:
• Incident report documentation dated 07/12/2024 authored
by Staff 4 was reviewed. It described that Youth A hit his
head on a window three times and then became more
aggressive towards Staff 4, first verbally and then
physically. Staff 4 attempted a standing restraint, only for
that to fail and for both individuals to fall to the ground.
Staff 4 then wrote that a supine restraint was used with the
assistance of other staff. Once the floor restraint ended
Youth A was seen by a staff nurse and then transported to
the hospital for further evaluation for a possible head injury.
• Personnel records for Staff 4 were reviewed. He was last
trained on the facility restraint model on 01/08/2024. Staff
4 does not have any discipline records in his file.
• Facility policy and procedures titled “Emergency Restraint:”
and last dated 07/18/2022 were reviewed. The facility
utilizes an approved restraint model in Non-Violent Crisis
Intervention. The policy stated that emergency restraints of
youth are to occur as an “emergency response to protect
youth or others from an unanticipated or severely
aggressive behavior that places the youth or others at
serious threat of violence or injury.”
6

• Facility policy and procedures titled “Prohibited Practices”
was provided and reviewed. This policy outlined prohibited
acts of staff towards youth, including “Hitting or striking,
throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a youth on any part of
their body.”
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per youth and staff
interviews and documentation reviewed. There was no evidence
found that Youth A was strangled or choked at any time during the
incident on 07/12/2024.
Technical Assistance provided:
• The facility is advised to discuss the initiation of restraints
and how body language and available staff can be utilized
to make them as safe as possible.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
